alert.note: Alert for Carbon (Wyoming) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Cheyenne (Southeastern Wyoming and Western Nebraska)
info.headline: Flood Watch issued May 20 at 10:58AM MDT until further notice by NWS Cheyenne
info.description: ...The Flood Watch continues for the following rivers in Wyoming... North Platte River at Saratoga affecting Carbon County. .Warm temperatures may melt high mountain snowpack and increase river flows. The North Platte River at Saratoga is currently in action stage and will approach minor flood stage as early as mid-day Monday. A River Flood Warning for the North Platte River at Saratoga will be likely Sunday into Monday and continue into at least early to mid-next week. River levels forecast to climb to just below 9 feet by Tuesday and remain elevated through the week near that level. Stay tuned for updates if forecasts increase for mid- to late-week. For the Upper North Platte River...including Saratoga, Sinclair... flooding is likely. ...FLOOD WATCH FOR SNOWMELT REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Flooding is possible. Increasing chances of minor flooding early to mid-week with Minor Flood Stage becoming more likely. * WHERE...North Platte River at Saratoga. * WHEN...Until further notice or until a River Flood Warning is issued. * IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, Flooding of low lying areas at the Deer Haven RV Park intensifies and becomes more widespread. Standing water inundates yards of homes along the river in town. Flood waters begin impacting access to Veterans Island Park. The golf course near the Saratoga Inn becomes inundated with water. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:45 AM MDT Saturday the stage was 8.0 feet. - Forecast...Flood stage may be reached early Monday afternoon. - Flood stage is 8.5 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Fld Observed Forecasts (12 pm MDT) Location Stg Stg Day/Time Sun Mon Tue North Platte River Saratoga 8.5 8.0 Sat 9 am MDT 8.3 8.5 8.8 &&
info.instruction: Residents and those with interests near the river should monitor rising water levels and be prepared for possible flood warnings. If you are in the watch area, remain alert to possible flooding. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued by Sunday morning at 1145am MDT.
